title: What are some good books on globalization? - Quora

response.answer_text: A book which I found balanced, informative, and well-written is Why Globalization Works by FT editor Martin Wolf. It was selected as a 2004 Book of the Year by the Economist, which writes:    The fullest and most sophisticated case yet for globalisation, by the chief economics commentator of the Financial Times. In plain, taut English, Martin Wolf argues that alleviating global poverty is the challenge of the age, and that the poorest countries in the world are poor not because of the baneful effects of too much globalisation, but rather because they stand outside the global economic system altogether. Mr Wolf pays a lot of attention to the interdependence of states and markets—and to the vital, even if limited, role that the state needs to play if countries are to prosper. The poorest countries, after all, are often failed states. Source: http://www.economist.com/node/3422856   Furthermore, the book is also frequently mentioned for its superior nature in contrast to Joseph Stiglitz's one-sided attack on the IMF in Globalization and Its Discontents, and Thomas Friedman's popular but slightly superficial The World is Flat.    More recently, just released World 3.0 by Pankaj Ghemawat has been getting good reviews and seems worth picking up.

I would recommend some novels: The God of Small Things by Arundhati RoyOne Hundred Years of Solitude by Gabriel Garcia MarquezAmericanah by Chimamanda Ngozi AdichieSuper Sad True Love Story by Gary Steyngart A Visit from the Goon Squad by Jennifer EganAfter Dark by Haruki MurakamiThe Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao by Junot DiazA Hologram for the King by Dave EggersTaipei by Tao LinMidnight's Children by Salman RushdieA Bend in the River by V.S. NaipaulSnow by Orhan PamukInterpreter of Maladies by Jhumpa Lahiri Although many of these might be better understood as postcolonial, I think they can contribute to one's understanding of globalization: specifically, the subjective experiences of people in dominant and domineered cultures, historical perspective on globalization, and memorable human faces put on complex issues.
